/wiki/Athletics_(sport): Athletics is a group of sporting events that involves competitive running, jumping, throwing, and walking. The most common types of athletics competitions are track and field, road running, cross country running, and race walking.
/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1951_Mediterranea: Athletics at the 1951 Mediterranean Games were held in Alexandria, Egypt.
/wiki/Bo%C5%BEidar_%C4%90ura%C5%A1kovi%C: Božidar Ðurašković (born 27 December 1924) is a former middle distance runner who competed in the 1952 Summer Olympics. He was born in Ulcinj.
/wiki/Branko_Dangubi%C4%87: Branko Dangubić (13 July 1922 in Ljubinje – 24 November 2002 in Belgrade) was a Serbian javelin thrower who competed in the 1952 Summer Olympics. He finished fifth. At the 1951 Mediterranean Games, he won a gold medal in the men's javelin throw.
/wiki/Zdravko_Ceraj:
Zdravko Ceraj (4 October 1920 – 6 October 2011) was a Croatian long-distance runner who competed for SFR Yugoslavia in the 1952 Summer Olympics. At the 1951 Mediterranean Games, he won a silver medal in 5000 m event. He was born in Bjelovar and died in Zagreb.
He competed for Partizan Belgrade.
/wiki/Franjo_Mihali%C4%87: Franjo Mihalić (Serbo-Croatian pronunciation: [frǎːɲo mǐxalitɕ]; 9 March 1920 – 14 February 2015) was a Croatian long-distance runner best known for his 1958 win at the Boston Marathon and his marathon silver medal in the 1956 Summer Olympics. Mihalić competed mostly in marathons, road races and cross country races, distinguishing himself by winning many top-level international competitions in the 1950s and setting a combined 25 Croatian and later Yugoslavian national records in long-distance track events between 5000 m and 25 km. In 1957, he became the inaugural winner of the Golden Badge, the award for the best sportsperson of Yugoslavia awarded by the daily Sport. He is regarded as the most accomplished male athlete in the history of Croatian, Serbian and Yugoslav track and field.
/wiki/Petar_%C5%A0egedin_(athlete): Petar Šegedin (14 September 1926 – 14 October 1994) was a Yugoslav steeplechase and long-distance runner.
/wiki/Andrija_Otenhajmer: Andrija Otenhajmer (16 October 1926 – 26 March 1999) was a Yugoslav middle-distance runner. He competed in the men's 1500 metres at the 1952 Summer Olympics.
/wiki/Marko_Ra%C4%8Di%C4%8D: Marko Račič (born April 25, 1920) is a Slovenian athlete who participated in the 1948 Summer Olympics in London, England. Representing Yugoslavia, he advanced to the semi-finals of the men's 400 metre competition, but did not make it beyond the opening round of the men's 4 x 400 metres relay. A local and state sprinting record holder, Račič competed internationally for many years and made appearances at the 1946 and 1950 European Athletics Championships prior to taking up personal training and coaching in 1953. He has served as an international athletics judge and an amateur sports administrator who was on committees for several international sporting events in Yugoslavia, including the 1984 Winter Olympics. Since June 2013, he has been the oldest living Slovenian Olympic competitor.
/wiki/Zvonko_Sabolovi%C4%87: Zvonko Sabolović (23 June 1923 – 5 May 2008) was a Yugoslavian sprinter. He competed in the men's 400 metres at the 1948 Summer Olympics.
/wiki/Ivan_Gubijan: Ivan Gubijan (14 June 1923 – 4 January 2009) was a Yugoslav hammer thrower. He competed in the 1948 and 1952 Olympics and placed second and ninth, respectively. He is credited with introducing the four-turn throwing technique, which is widely used today.
/wiki/Stevan_Pavlovi%C4%87: Stevan Pavlović (16 May 1926 – 30 July 1998) was a Serbian long-distance runner who competed for SFR Yugoslavia in the 1952 Summer Olympics.
/wiki/Mihajlo_Dimitrijevi%C4%87: Mihajlo Dimitrijević (May 27, 1927 – November 2, 1995) was a Serbian high jumper who competed for SFR Yugoslavia in the 1952 Summer Olympics.
/wiki/Rudolf_Galin: Rudolf Galin (1 April 1928 – 8 August 2004) was a Croatian athlete. He competed in the men's hammer throw at the 1952 Summer Olympics.
/wiki/Yugoslavia_at_the_1951_Mediterrane: Yugoslavia competed at the 1951 Mediterranean Games held in Alexandria, Egypt.
